outputs.literature: The patient is placed in the supine position with the head turned towards the opposite shoulder. The operator sits at the head of the patient with the ultrasound machine positioned facing him, next to the patient's trunk on the same side as the block, to maintain the straight line from eye to screen in a comfortable position for the operator. Although a linear probe can be used, a small high-frequency curved-array probe, if available, is recommended as this provides a broader view at the depth of 4–6 cm which may be required for this approach (Video 3, Fig. 4). In addition, it facilitates in-plane needle placement below a prominent clavicle. We routinely use a small 9–3 MHz curved-array probe with an 80 mm, 22 g block needle placed immediately below the clavicle, medial to the coracoid process, to get an optimal short-axis view in a para-sagittal plane. Typically, the axillary artery is surrounded by the three hyperechoic round cords (lateral, posterior, and medial) of the plexus, named after their anatomical position with respect to the axillary artery. An ultrasound enhancement artifact below the artery can frequently be confused with the posterior cord. This phenomenon is seen when tissues appear more echogenic and bright when visualized through a fluid-filled structure such as blood vessels. The posterior cord is more commonly visualized lying below the lateral cord. (Fig. 4) The axillary vein can be seen lying anatomically medial to the axillary artery. The needle is inserted in-plane, under the clavicle (above the probe) and the local anaesthetic is placed postero-lateral to the axillary artery (8 o’clock position) ensuring a good spread around the artery (double–bubble sign). The needle may have to be advanced slightly towards a ‘6 o’clock’ position to ensure spread below and around the artery towards the medial cord. Bowens et al.8 demonstrated a 96% success rate when the posterior cord (6 o'clock position) was targeted during the block and all patients had a pain score ≤3 in the postoperative period. Using ultrasound-guidance has improved the efficacy of this technique, although the minimum effective local anaesthetic volume in 90% patients remains ∼35 ml.
outputs.clinic_output:
Initial Probe Placement:
1. Transducer Type: High-frequency linear, 10-15 MHz.
2. Patient Position: Supine, head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally, shoulder depressed.
3. Probe Placement: Transversely above clavicle, slight caudad tilt.

Landmark Identification:
1. Axillary Artery (AA): Hyperechoic, pulsatile structure within the red circle.
2. Axillary Vein (AV): Anechoic, compressible structure within the blue circle, located medial to the AA.
3. Pectoral Major Muscle (P): Hyperechoic, curved structure superficial to the AA and AV.
4. Pectoral Minor Muscle (L): Hyperechoic, thin, triangular structure deep to the P and lateral to the AA and AV.
5. Clavicle: Hyperechoic, curved structure at the top of the image, superior to the AA and AV.
6. Chest Wall: Hyperechoic, linear structure on the right side of the image, lateral to the AA and AV.

Tips for Optimizing Image:
1. Depth: Adjust the depth to 2-4 cm to optimize visualization of the AA, AV, and surrounding musculature.
2. Gain: Optimize the gain to enhance visualization of the AA, AV, and surrounding structures without over-saturating the image.
3. Probe Pressure: Apply slight pressure with the probe to improve the resolution and reduce artifact from the clavicle.

Needle Path & Safety Tips:
1. Needle Approach: In-plane, lateral-to-medial approach from the lateral aspect of the probe.
2. Target Location: Aim for the AA, avoiding the AV and surrounding musculature.
3. Structures to Avoid: Avoid the AA, as it may result in local anesthetic uptake by the vessel, and the clavicle due to the risk of bone contact.
4. Injection Technique: Inject 1-2 mL aliquots under real-time ultrasound guidance, ensuring the local anesthetic spreads around the AA without intravascular uptake.

outputs.literature: Patient is supine or sitting with head turned to contralateral side and the shoulder abducted to 90 degrees. The probe is placed in a parasagittal orientation just medial coracoid process and inferior to the clavicle. It may be easiest to first palpate the coracoid process as this is a key landmark. Begin scanning just medial to the coracoid, keeping the probe in a sagittal orientation. Scan medially and laterally until you identify the axillary artery with surrounding brachial plexus cords. Be sure to identify the pleura posterior to the axillary artery.  If pleura is seen you need to slide laterally until serratus anterior appears. This should be done to minimize risk of pneumothorax. The brachial plexus cords (lateral, medial, and posterior) surround the axillary artery in a variable pattern but cannot always be individually visualized. The goal is anesthetic spread around the axillary artery. Once this view is obtained, an in-plane approach should be used. The needle should be inserted just inferior to the clavicle and aimed caudal towards the posterior aspect of the axillary artery.
outputs.clinic_output:
Initial Probe Placement:
1. Transducer: Use a high-frequency linear transducer (e.g., 10-15 MHz).
2. Patient Position: The patient should be positioned supine with their head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally and the shoulder depressed.
3. Probe Placement: Place the transducer transversely above the clavicle and apply a slight caudad tilt.

Landmark Identification:
1. Pec Major: The Pec Major muscle appears as a hyperechoic structure in the upper region of the image.
2. Pec Minor: The Pec Minor muscle is visualized as a deeper hyperechoic structure beneath the Pec Major muscle.
3. Axillary Artery (AA): The AA is identified as an anechoic tubular structure in the lower region of the image.
4. Axillary Vein (AV): The AV is also an anechoic tubular structure located alongside the AA in the lower region.
5. Mediopectus Caudalis (MC): The MC muscle is visualized as a hyperechoic structure in the image.
6. Pectoral Calf (PC): The PC muscle is another hyperechoic structure visible in the image.

Tips for Optimizing Image:
1. Depth: Adjust the depth to 2-4 cm to optimize visualization of the target structures.
2. Gain: Optimize the gain to enhance the visualization of the nerves, vessels, and surrounding musculature.
3. Probe Pressure: Apply

outputs.literature: Any position that allows for the comfortable placement of the ultrasound transducer and needle advancement is appropriate. The nerve block is typically performed with the patient in the supine position with the head turned away from the side to be blocked (Figure 4). The arm is abducted to 90 degrees and the elbow flexed. This maneuver raises the clavicle, reduces the depth from the skin to the plexus, and substantially facilitates visualization of the pectoralis muscles as well as the cords of the brachial plexus and the needle. The coracoid process is an important landmark and can be easily identified by palpating the bony prominence just medial to the shoulder while the arm is elevated and lowered. As the arm is lowered, the coracoid process meets the fingers of the palpating hand. Scanning usually begins just medial to the coracoid process and inferior to the clavicle. Keeping the probe in a parasagittal plane, scanning medially and laterally allows the chest wall and pleura to be located (Figure 5). The nerve block should be performed with the probe lateral to the pleura in order to minimize the risk of pneumothorax. With the patient in the proper position, the skin is disinfected and the transducer is positioned in the parasagittal plane to identify the axillary artery (see Figure 3 and 4). This may require adjustment of the depth, depending on the thickness of the patient’s chest wall musculature. The axillary artery is typically seen between 3 and 5 cm. Once the artery has been identified, an attempt is made to identify the hyperechoic cords of the brachial plexus and their corresponding positions relative to the artery, although these may not always be identifiable. Fortunately, visualization of the cords are not necessary for successful block. The needle is inserted in-plane from the cephalad end of the probe, with the insertion point just inferior to the clavicle (see Figure 4). The needle is aimed toward the posterior aspect of the axillary artery and passes through the pectoralis major and minor muscles. If nerve stimulation is used concurrently (0.5–0.8 mA, 0.1 msec), the first motor response is often from the lateral cord (either elbow flexion or finger flexion). As the needle is advanced farther beneath the artery, a posterior cord motor response may appear (finger and wrist extension). After careful aspiration, 1–2 mL of local anesthetic is injected to confirm proper needle placement and spread. The injectate should spread cephalad and caudad to cover the lateral and medial cords, respectively (Figure 6).
outputs.clinic_output:
Initial Probe Placement:
1. Transducer Type: Use a high-frequency linear transducer (10-15 MHz).
2. Patient Position: Position the patient supine with their head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally and shoulder depressed.
3. Probe Placement and Tilt: Place the transducer transversely above the clavicle with a slight caudad tilt.

Landmark Identification:
1. Pectoralis Major Muscle: The pectoralis major muscle appears as a hyperechoic (bright) structure at the upper part of the image.
2. Pectoralis Minor Muscle: The pectoralis minor muscle is visible below the pectoralis major muscle and appears as a hypoechoic (darker) structure.
3. Axillary Artery (AA) and Axillary Vein (AV): The axillary artery and vein are situated in the central area of the image and appear as anechoic (black) structures.
4. Clavicle (LC) and Pectoralis Cap (PC): The clavicle and pectoralis cap are labeled on the left side of the image and appear as hyperechoic structures.
5. Pleura: The pleura is visible on the right side of the image and appears as a hyperechoic line.

Tips for Optimizing Image:
1. Depth Adjustment: Adjust the depth of the ultrasound machine to 2-4 cm to improve visualization of the brachial plexus structures.
2. Gain Adjustment: Optimize the gain settings to enhance the differentiation between the various structures.
3. Probe Pressure and Tilt: Apply slight pressure and tilt adjustments to improve the quality of the image and better visualize the nerves and vessels.

Needle Path & Safety Tips:
1. Needle Approach: Use an in-plane approach from lateral to medial for the brachial plexus block.
2. Target Location: Aim for the area between the pectoralis major and minor muscles, near the axillary artery and vein.
3. Structures to Avoid: Avoid puncturing the pleura, axillary artery, or axillary vein during the procedure.
4. Injection Technique: Inject 1-2 mL aliquots under real-time ultrasound guidance to ensure proper placement and avoid injury.

outputs.literature: Place the transducer below the clavicle, medial to the coracoid process with the probe positioned in a parasagittal fashion (Figure 6). Identify the axillary artery, which lies posterior to the pectoralis major and minor muscles. The axillary artery is typically located at a depth of 3 to 4.5 cm. It is seen as a dark, round, pulsating structure with a hyperechoic wall (Figure 3). The axillary vein usually lies beside the artery (medially and inferiorly), and it very easily collapses with compression. Hence, additional attention should be paid to the vein to prevent inadvertent puncture of the vessel. A combination of 2-dimensional and colour Doppler will allow identification of arterial and venous anatomy and confirm their position. Be mindful that the brachial plexus in the infraclavicular region is deeper compared with other sites (4 cm), and the location of the cords around the axillary artery can vary significantly (Figure 2). The axillary artery is surrounded by 3 hyperechoic circular cords of the brachial plexus: the lateral, posterior, and medial cords. These have a honeycomb appearance. The lateral cord generally lies superior (cranial) to the axillary artery, and the posterior and medial cords lie posteriorly and inferiorly (cephalad) to the axillary artery, respectively (Figures 3 and 4). Place 2 mL of 1% to 2% lidocaine subcutaneously prior to placement of the block needle. Reconfirm the sonoanatomy with US and anchor the probe by placing your hand on the patient’s torso. Using an in-plane needle technique, from cephalad to caudad, visualise the needle throughout the performance of the block. Place the needle inferior to the clavicle and direct the needle inferiorly toward the posterior aspect of the axillary artery. The skin, subcutaneous tissue, pectoralis major, and pectoralis minor are penetrated en route toward the infraclavicular plexus (Figure 7). The angle of approach is very acute, which requires the direction of the needle to be quite steep. This will make concurrent visualisation of the needle and the surrounding anatomy challenging. A ‘‘heel-in’’ manoeuvre (as described below) may help to improve the view and allow more space on the skin below the clavicle to insert the needle (Figure 9). As the needle is advanced under US guidance, with a nerve stimulator connected with a stimulation current of 0.5 mA to 1 mA at 0.1 seconds, the lateral cord motor response will be manifested as elbow or finger flexion. Reducing the stimulating current to 0.2 mA with no motor manifestations of lateral cord response would deem it safe to begin deposition of LA in this location.
outputs.clinic_output:
Initial Probe Placement:
1. Transducer type: High-frequency linear, 10-15 MHz.
2. Patient position: Supine, head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally, shoulder depressed.
3. Probe placement: Transversely above clavicle.
4. Tilt: Slight caudad tilt.

Landmark Identification:
1. Pectoralis Major muscle: Hyperechoic structure at the top of the image.
2. Pectoralis Minor muscle: Hyperechoic structure below the Pectoralis Major muscle.
3. Axillary artery (AA): Anechoic tubular structure.
4. Axillary vein (AV): Anechoic tubular structure.
5. Common carotid artery (LC): Anechoic tubular structure.
6. Posterior cardinal artery (PC): Anechoic tubular structure.

Tips for Optimizing Image:
1. Adjust depth: 2-4 cm.
2. Adjust gain: As necessary to improve visualization.
3. Apply slight probe pressure: To enhance nerve and vessel visualization.
4. Tilt: Make adjustments to optimize the view.

Needle Path & Safety Tips:
1. Needle approach: In-plane, lateral-to-medial.
2. Target location: Below the Pectoralis Minor muscle and lateral to the axillary artery.
3. Structures to avoid: Pleura, axillary artery, and veins.
4. Injection technique: Inject 1-2 mL aliquots under real-time ultrasound guidance.

outputs.literature: With this technique, the needle is more likely to contact the plexus distal to the coracoid process5 6 and is more likely to miss or partially anaesthetize the axillary and musculocutaneous nerves. We use a technique in which the arm is abducted 110°, externally rotated and the elbow is flexed 90°. The puncture is made at the apex of the delto-pectoral groove in the sagittal plane (Fig. 1). We call this the medial infraclavicular technique (MIT). We use this proximal approach because the cords are grouped close together, superior to the axillary artery, at this location in the plexus (Fig. 2) and they may lie closer to the skin. As one moves distally along the plexus, the medial cord comes to lie between the axillary artery and vein where it may be more difficult to block (Fig 3, Fig 4). In addition, abducting and externally rotating the arm may bring the plexus closer to the surface of the skin and further away from the ribs and pleura.
outputs.clinic_output:
Initial Probe Placement
1. Transducer Type: High-frequency linear, 10-15 MHz
2. Patient Position: Supine, head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally, shoulder depressed
3. Probe Placement: Transversely above clavicle
4. Tilt: Slight caudad tilt

Landmark Identification
1. Pectoralis Major and Minor: Hyperechoic, vertical muscles on either side of the image
2. Inferior Pectoralis: Hyperechoic, vertical muscle at the bottom of the image
3. Lateral Cord: Central, vertically extending structure
4. S1-Suprascapular: Structure running along the top of the lateral cord
5. P2-Posterior: Structure running along the bottom of the lateral cord
6. E3-Erector Spinae: Structure running along the back of the lateral cord
7. O4-Obturator: Structure running along the bottom of the lateral cord
8. R5-Rami Radiatum: Branching nerve roots from the lateral cord
9. Medial Cord: Central, vertically extending structure
10. Posterior Cord: Vertically extending structure
11. Artery and Vein: Not visible in this image

Tips for Optimizing Image
1. Depth: Adjust to 2-4 cm
2. Gain: Optimize for better visualization of nerves and surrounding musculature
3. Probe Pressure: Apply slight pressure to enhance image quality
4. Tilt: Make slight adjustments to improve visibility of target structures
5. Doppler: Use color Doppler to aid in identifying vessels

Needle Path & Safety Tips
1. Needle Approach: In-plane, lateral-to-medial
2. Target Location: Aim for the lateral cord, avoiding nearby vessels and nerves
3. Structures to Avoid: Pleura, arteries/veins, phrenic nerve
4. Injection Technique: Inject 1-2 mL aliquots under real-time ultrasound guidance

outputs.literature: The patient should be placed in the supine position. The transducer is placed in a parasagittal position below the clavicle on the medial aspect of the coracoid process (Figure 9.3). Depending on the size and body habitus of the child, a probe with a short linear length such as 25 mm may be required. Some adjustment of the probe in multiple planes may be necessary to achieve a satisfactory view of the artery and the surrounding cords. Abduction of the arm to 90 degrees may be helpful by moving the acromioclavicular junction superiorly. In younger or thin children a high frequency linear probe may be sufficient for visualization of the infraclavicular fossa while a lower frequency curved array probe may be necessary in larger children and adolescents to visualize a deeper infraclavicular fossa. Color Doppler may be useful to verify the position of the axillary artery and vein. The lateral cord is seen as a hyperechoic structure as is the posterior cord, which can be seen posterior to the axillary artery at the 6 o’clock position. The medial cord may be more difficult to visualize but the injection of 1–2 ml of LA anterior to the artery may improve its localization. For single injection a 22-gauge needle can be used and the length of needle (50–100 mm) can be chosen based on the child’s size and plexus depth. A 25 mm BP needle may be sufficient in infants and small children while a 100 mm BP needle may be required to reach the infraclavicular fossa in adolescents. The needle is then inserted between the coracoid process and the superior portion of the ultrasound probe. The needle is advanced in-plane through the pectoralis major and minor muscles (Figure 9.4). Because of the steep needle angle required to reach the infraclavicular BP, the needle image may not be very clear so care must be taken to monitor tissue displacement as the needle is advanced in an effort to avoid puncturing the artery. The LA is injected in small 3–5 ml increments around the cords ensuring that there is adequate perivascular spread of the LA, especially medially and laterally around the artery. Current recommended volumes are 0.5 ml/kg of 0.2% ropivacaine or 0.25% bupivacaine, although these volumes may reduce with the increasing experience with ultrasound to guide LA deposition for this block.
outputs.clinic_output:
Initial Probe Placement:
1. Use a high-frequency linear transducer (10-15 MHz).
2. Position the patient supine with the head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally and the shoulder depressed.
3. Place the probe transversely above the clavicle with a slight caudad tilt.

Landmark Identification:
1. Pectoralis Major Muscle (pectoralis major m.): Hyperechoic, appears as a large chest muscle at the top of the image.
2. Pectoralis Minor Muscle (pec minor m.): Positioned beneath the pectoralis major muscle, contributing to the formation of the pectoralis major.
3. Axillary Artery (AA): Visible in the image as a major blood vessel supplying the arm.
4. Pectoralis Major Tendon (PC): Connects the pectoralis major muscle to the shoulder.
5. Clavicle (LC): Visible as a horizontal structure, the long bone of the shoulder.
6. Clavicular Collateral Ligament (MC): A ligament that stabilizes the clavicle.
7. Pectoralis Major (pleura): The main muscle of the chest, visible as a prominent structure in the image.
8. Lung: Part of the respiratory system, visible as a fluid-filled cavity.

Tips for Optimizing Image:
1. Adjust the depth of the ultrasound machine to 2-4 cm to better visualize the target structures.
2. Optimize the gain settings to enhance the visibility of nerves, vessels, pleura, or surrounding musculature.
3. Apply slight probe pressure and adjust the tilt to improve the quality of the image.

Needle Path & Safety Tips:
1. Use an in-plane approach from lateral to medial for the needle insertion.
2. Target the location between the pectoralis major and minor muscles, avoiding the axillary artery and other vessels.
3. Avoid puncturing the pleura or lung during the procedure.
4. Inject 1-2 mL aliquots under real-time ultrasound guidance to ensure accurate delivery of the anesthetic.

outputs.literature: Any position that allows comfortable placement of the ultrasound transducer and needle advancement is appropriate. The block is typically performed with the patient in supine position with the head turned away from the side to be blocked. The arm is abducted to 90° and the elbow flexed. This maneuver reduces the depth from the skin to the plexus and substantially facilitates visualization of the pectoralis muscles as well as the cords of the brachial plexus. With the patient in the proper position, the skin is disinfected and the transducer is positioned in the parasagittal plane to identify the axillary artery. This may require adjustment of the depth, depending on the thickness of the patient’s chest wall musculature. The axillary artery (or the transition of the subclavian to axillary artery) is typically seen between 3 and 5 cm. Once the artery is identified, an attempt is made to identify the hyperechoic cords of the brachial plexus and their corresponding positions relative to the artery, although these may not always be identifiable. Fortunately, exhaustive efforts to visualize the cords are not necessary for successful blockade. The needle is inserted in-plane from the cephalad aspect, with the insertion point just inferior to the clavicle. The needle is aimed toward the posterior aspect of the axillary artery and passes through the pectoralis major and minor muscles. If nerve stimulation is used concurrently (0.5-0.8 mA, 0.1 msec), the first motor response is often from the lateral cord (either elbow flexion or finger flexion). As the needle is further advanced beneath the artery, a posterior cord motor response may appear (finger and wrist extension). After careful aspiration, 1 to 2 mL of local anesthetic is injected to confirm the proper needle placement and spread. The injectate should spread cephalad and caudad to cover the lateral and medial cords, respectively.
outputs.clinic_output:
Initial Probe Placement:
1. Transducer Type: A high-frequency linear probe, typically 10-15 MHz, should be used for this block.
2. Patient Position: The patient should be positioned supine with their head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally and shoulder depressed.
3. Probe Placement: Place the probe transversely above the clavicle, slightly tilted caudad if necessary.

Landmark Identification:
1. PmM (Pectoral Muscles): The pectoral muscles are identified as the hyperechoic structure at the upper portion of the image.
2. PMII (Pectoral Major Muscle Inner Part): A portion of the pectoral major muscle appears as an anechoic area labeled as PMII.
3. MC (Medial Conduit): The medial conduit is identified by a yellow arrow, indicating a passage for the brachial plexus.
4. Eccia: The Eccia region is marked with an arrow, indicating a specific area or structure related to the brachial plexus.
5. LC (Lateral Conduit): The lateral conduit is identified by a yellow arrow, indicating another key passageway for the brachial plexus.
6. PC (Posterior Conduit): The posterior conduit is marked with a yellow arrow, indicating its location within the brachial plexus.
7. AA (Axillary Artery): The axillary artery is visible and marked, appearing as a pulsatile anechoic structure.
8. AV (Axillary Vein): The axillary vein is also present and marked, appearing as an anechoic structure adjacent to the artery.

Tips for Optimizing Image:
1. Depth Adjustment: Adjust the depth to 2-4 cm to optimize visualization of the brachial plexus structures.
2. Gain Adjustment: Optimize the gain settings to improve visualization of nerves, vessels, and surrounding musculature.
3. Probe Pressure: Apply slight pressure with the probe to enhance contact and improve image quality.
4. Doppler: Consider using Doppler ultrasound to aid in differentiating vessels from other structures.

Needle Path & Safety Tips:
1. Needle Approach: Use an in-plane lateral-to-medial approach for this block.
2. Target Location: Aim to place the needle near the brachial plexus within the identified conduits (MC, LC, or PC).
3. Structures to Avoid: Avoid puncturing the pleura, axillary artery, axillary vein, or phrenic nerve.
4. Injection Technique: Inject 1-2 mL aliquots under real-time ultrasound guidance to ensure accurate delivery of anesthetic.

outputs.literature: The probe is oriented in a parasagittal plane so as to cut across the axillary artery in the short axis. The probe location can be anywhere from the mid-clavicle to the coracoid. Visualize two major vascular structures, the axillary artery and vein deep to the pectoralis minor muscle belly. The artery is on the cephalad side of the vein, and is rounder and less compressible than the vein. If more than two vessels are seen, slide probe medially, simplifying the image as branches of vessels rejoin the major trunks. The nerves of the plexus may or may not be visualized as hyperechoic structures surrounding the artery. The lateral cord is on the cephalad side of the artery, the posterior cord posterior to the artery, and the medial cord on the caudal side of the artery, often between it and the vein. The needle is introduced from the cephalad side of the ultrasound probe, in plane with the beam so as to allow the needle path to be visualized from the start. The goal is to place the needle just alongside the cephalad portion of the artery. Injection of local anesthetic can then commence in small increments (with frequent aspiration to ensure no intravascular placement). It is very important to pay attention to the spread of the local anesthetic, since, as mentioned previously, there are fascial divisions described in this portion of the plexus inhibiting full spread from a single injection site. If full spread of the local anesthetic around the artery is not seen surrounding it like a doughnut (except for the most superficial side of the artery), reposition the needle under direct visualization. Usually one repositioning is enough to complete the spread. Some practitioners like to inject separately along the caudal side of the artery to assure better spread to this portion of the plexus sheath. Careful to make sure that the needle does not enter the artery or the vein during injection. Volumes employed are 30-40 ml of local anesthetic solution.
outputs.clinic_output:
Initial Probe Placement:
1. Transducer Type: High-frequency linear, 10-15 MHz.
2. Patient Position: Supine, head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally, shoulder depressed.
3. Probe Placement: Transversely above clavicle, slight caudad tilt.

Landmark Identification:
1. Pectoralis Major Muscle: Hyperechoic, appears as a thick, curved structure at the top of the image.
2. Pectoralis Minor Muscle: Hyperechoic, appears as a thinner, triangular structure below the pectoralis major muscle.
3. Axillary Artery (AA): Anechoic, appears as a round or oval structure running along the lateral aspect of the image, marked with a red "A".
4. Axillary Vein (AV): Anechoic, appears as a round or oval structure positioned laterally and slightly medial to the axillary artery, marked with a blue "V".
5. Latissimus Dorsi Muscle: Hyperechoic, appears as a curved structure on the lateral aspect of the image.

Tips for Optimizing Image:
1. Adjustments to depth: 2-4 cm.
2. Adjustments to gain: Optimize to enhance visualization of nerves, vessels, and surrounding musculature.
3. Probe Pressure: Apply slight pressure to improve image quality without compressing the axillary vessels.
4. Tilt: Slight caudad tilt may help optimize the view of the axillary artery and vein.
5. Doppler: Use color Doppler to aid in identifying the axillary artery and vein.

Needle Path & Safety Tips:
1. Needle Approach: In-plane, lateral-to-medial.
2. Target Location: Position the needle tip near the axillary artery, avoiding the axillary vein and surrounding musculature.
3. Structures to Avoid: Pleura, axillary artery, axillary vein, and the nearby phrenic nerve.
4. Injection Technique: Inject 1-2 mL aliquots under real-time ultrasound guidance to ensure accurate placement and avoid nerve damage.

outputs.literature: The patient is positioned in a semi-recumbent position. The head is turned to the contralateral side. The clavicle and coracoid process are palpated. A high-frequency linear transducer is placed in a sagittal plane 1–2 cm inferior and medial to the coracoid process. The pectoralis major (PMM) and pectoralis minor (PmM) muscles should be visible, with the axillary artery pulsating beneath the PmM. The three cords of the brachial plexus should be seen around the artery (see Fig. 4). An echogenic, blunt-tip block needle is inserted below the clavicle and advanced in-plane from cranial to caudal, directed toward the 6-o'clock position of the axillary artery. The injectate should appear to spread to either sides of the artery, and the artery is lifted superficially.
outputs.clinic_output:
Initial Probe Placement:
1. Transducer Type: High-frequency linear array (10-15 MHz)
2. Patient Position: Supine, head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally, shoulder depressed
3. Probe Placement: Transversely above clavicle
4. Tilt: Slight caudad tilt

Landmark Identification:
1. Axillary Artery (AA): Hyperechoic structure
2. Axillary Vein (AV): Anechoic structure
3. Posterior Cord (PC): Hyperechoic structure
4. Lateral Cord (LC): Hyperechoic structure
5. Posterior Cord (PMC): Hyperechoic structure

Tips for Optimizing Image:
1. Depth adjustment: 2-4 cm
2. Gain adjustment: 50 dB
3. Probe pressure adjustment: Apply slight pressure to improve image quality
4. Tilt adjustment: Slight caudad tilt
5. Use Doppler to aid in identifying vessels (AA and AV)

Needle Path & Safety Tips:
1. Needle Approach: In-plane, lateral-to-medial
2. Target Location: Lateral to the axillary artery (AA)
3. Structures to avoid: Pleura, axillary artery (AA), axillary vein (AV), phrenic nerve
4. Injection technique: Inject 1-2 mL aliquots under real-time ultrasound guidance.  Note: This clinical advice is specific to the described ultrasound image. Always assess individual patient anatomy and adjust accordingly.

outputs.literature: Select a linear high-frequency probe. Adjust gain, focus and depth 3–4 cm.Turn the orientation mark on the probe cranially. Place the probe below the clavicle, medial to the coracoid process in the parasagittal plane. Locate the black, pulsatile axillary artery (AA) and align it to the centre of the monitor. Seeing AA as a clock face the lateral cord is located at nine o’clock, the posterior cord at six o’clock and the medial cord at two o’clock. Often the cords are not sonographically visible. Insert the needle below the clavicle and advance it in-plane aiming periarterially at seven o’clock. Empty the needle of air by injecting 1/2 mL local anaesthetic subcutaneously. Avoid piercing any vessels or nerves. The endpoint of injection is periarterially from two o’clock to ten o’clock. Reposition the needle tip as necessary to reach the endpoint
outputs.clinic_output:
Initial Probe Placement:
1. Use a high-frequency linear transducer, such as a 10-15 MHz linear probe.
2. Place the patient in a supine position with their head turned 30-45 degrees contralaterally and their shoulder depressed.
3. Position the transducer transversely above the clavicle with a slight caudad tilt.

Landmark Identification:
1. Identify the hyperechoic (bright) appearance of the clavicle.
2. Visualize the brachial plexus as a group of hypoechoic (darker) structures posterior to the clavicle.
3. Note the presence of the subclavian artery, which appears as an anechoic (black) structure.
4. Identify the pleura, which can be seen as a hyperechoic linear structure deep to the brachial plexus.

Tips for Optimizing Image:
1. Adjust the depth of the ultrasound image to 2-4 cm to ensure optimal visualization of the brachial plexus.
2. Optimize the gain settings to enhance the differentiation between different tissues.
3. Apply slight pressure with the transducer to improve image quality.
4. Use Doppler ultrasound if available to help identify vessels.

Needle Path & Safety Tips:
1. Insert the needle in-plane from a lateral-to-medial direction.
2. Target the brachial plexus at a location posterior to the clavicle.
3. Avoid puncturing the pleura or subclavian artery.
4. Use real-time ultrasound guidance and inject 1-2 mL aliquots of local anesthetic solution.
